document.title: AP Microeconomics Course and Exam Description

0732B47527324FD6982D68649AA481D9.description:
Sources of income and wealth inequality include differences
in tax structures (progressive and regressive tax structures),
human capital, social capital, inheritance, effects of
discrimination, access to financial markets, mobility, and
bargaining power within economic and social units (firms, labor
unions, and families).

CC98887E48774761A5C6752F953ADE29.description:
Each factor of production receives the value of its marginal
product, which can contribute to income inequality.

DD6411EFD9BE491AA3EF5DB2153F8D2A.description:
Explain sources of income
and wealth inequality

33556AF860BD4502A2E0E5BF3BC21788.description:
The Lorenz curve and Gini coefficient are used to represent
the degree of inequality in distributions and to compare
distributions across different countries, policies, or
time periods.

4FA47CFF545346299CBF9EE91812A01D.description:
Income levels and poverty rates vary greatly both across and
within groups (e.g., age, gender, race) and countries

1754DE0A5D8C47069A2439DE2CEB7F10.description:
Define measures of economic
inequality in income and
wealth.

5706AACD2CCA4C0194F27882A8C41035.description:
Market outcomes
can result in income
inequality

CDC08642159F4C4997BD012D60FF7C2E.description:
Governments use antitrust policy in an attempt to make
markets more competitive.

5BDFD0750CBE42088AC2E31C57E2D8CD.description:
A natural monopoly will require a lump-sum subsidy to produce
at the allocatively efficient quantity

003DD4E353AD4BDD92CF7FFC4647A657.description:
Government can use price regulation to address inefficiency
due to monopoly.

77D670EE1DDF4DDB8BF4FD144A7E6513.description:
Government intervention in imperfect markets can increase
efficiency if the policy correctly addresses the incentives that
led to the market failure.

953BA11885EA4189AEC02AAF1D59AD94.description:
Binding price ceilings and floors affect prices and quantities
differently depending on the market structures (perfect
competition, monopoly, monopolistic competition, and
monopsony) and the price elasticities of supply and demand.

1B7FEB72AE424C1D8DEEB4F4B40E56F2.description:
Lump-sum taxes and lump-sum subsidies do not change
either marginal cost or marginal benefit; only fixed costs will
be affected.

D38E0470B786404CA70372DEC7569727.description:
Per-unit taxes and subsidies affect the total price consumers
pay, net price firms receive, equilibrium quantity, consumer and
producer surpluses, deadweight loss, and government revenue
or cost. The impact of change depends on the price elasticity
of demand and supply

A2B1D640692C4B42A596947685C20FC9.description:
Define government policy
interventions in imperfect
markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
government policies can
alter market outcomes in
perfectly and imperfectly
competitive markets.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from government policies
in perfectly competitive
and imperfectly
competitive markets.

F6E974BD425E4735A45470903BED5E0D.description:
In imperfect markets,
well-designed
government policy can
reduce waste.

6B06B88C94DF430EAEC59717F285F6D7.description:
Some natural resources are, by their nature, non-excludable and
rival and therefore open access. Private individuals inefficiently
overconsume such resources.

BAF43EF5A469489CA5F794405E51FBF0.description:
Governments sometimes choose to produce private goods,
such as educational services, and to allow free access to them.

27E99BA0EB714E62AB3BA08F1C3C2F65.description:
Due to the free rider problem, private individuals usually lack the
incentive to produce public goods, leaving government as the
only producer.

20680299908B43038FBE330AC5E62231.description:
Private goods are rival and excludable, and public goods are
non-rival and non-excludable.

58C1156206CC46C5B7C8A9A567BD861C.description:
Define whether goods are
rival and/or excludable.
b. Explain how the nature
of rival and/or excludable
goods influences the
behavior of individuals
and groups.

86F0A33CE6734AB296C8162F13B2DA35.description:
Policies that address positive or negative externalities include
taxes/subsidies, environmental regulation, public provision,
the assignment of property rights, and the reassignment of
property rights through private transactions.

4AF3272CE36B43C1A34FD5796F0ACDA0.description:
Explain (using graphs where
appropriate) how public
policies address positive or
negative externalities.

A26E705064E243339D6F436338D3BABF.description:
Rational agents have the incentive to free ride when a good is
non-excludable.

4C2076227E0643768B913E836B62DC6E.description:
In the presence of externalities, rational agents respond to private
costs and benefits and not to external costs and benefits.

E403CD2970EC48D3B0520DCB1C3ED60A.description:
Externalities are either positive or negative and arise from lack
of well-defined property rights and/or high transaction costs.

521F342C4E3648ABB998C9B228371892.description:
The socially optimal quantity of a good occurs where the
marginal social benefit of consuming the last unit equals the
marginal social cost of producing that last unit, thus maximizing
total economic surplus.

58840CFBAD61443191BC9115A0D3D115.description:
a. Define externalities.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
how in the presence
of externalities, private
markets do not take into
consideration social
costs or social benefits.

4F94481606254ED0A2044ED312EB68FB.description:
Private incentives
can fail to account for
all socially relevant
considerations.

D1506FE7EC1040E3BCEEB505BD66EEF7.description: Producing any non-efficient quantity results in deadweight loss.

344BA0EF1F514273B8B9F74163C5ED07.description:
Equilibrium allocations can deviate from efficient allocations
due to situations such as monopoly; oligopoly; monopolistic
competition; negative and positive externalities in production
or consumption; asymmetric information; and insufficient
production of public goods.

62C4306C843E4742B980F5E8B5EF990D.description:
a. Explain equilibrium
allocations in imperfect
markets relative to efficient
allocations (using graphs
where appropriate),
and why these markets
are inefficient.
b. Calculate (using graphs
where appropriate) the
deadweight loss resulting
from the production of a
non-efficient quantity

0A75658A10E041F49E07A4EFF794B3DF.description:
Market inefficiencies can be eliminated by designing policies
that equate marginal social benefit with marginal social cost.

40F2FD23F4F14021884C5BF9DF01AE3F.description:
Policymakers use cost-benefit analysis to evaluate different
actions to reduce or eliminate market inefficiencies.

0B5F74A748384DACBC5F9C2F9E544803.description:
Rational agents make optimal decisions by equating private
marginal benefits and private marginal costs that can result in
market inefficiencies.

AFD731B982E6402B976E156377841E98.description:
Rational agents can pursue private actions to exploit or exercise
market characteristics known as market power.

332F3EE671BE4C35B1AEF4CB9F4B0D96.description:
Explain (using graphs where
appropriate) how private
incentives can lead to
actions by rational agents
that are socially undesirable
(inefficient) market outcomes

B9BBF3F31E6846C3954F594A4C0A0FD3.description:
The market equilibrium quantity is equal to the socially optimal
quantity only when all social benefits and costs are internalized
by individuals in the market. Total economic surplus is
maximized at that quantity.

C3616D467E274CE4B5C1E0A04A5FCBB9.description:
The optimal quantity of a good occurs where the marginal
benefit of consuming the last unit equals the marginal
cost of producing that last unit, thus maximizing total
economic surplus.

DD369008D45F4B8B915782B30153E2B5.description:
a. Define social efficiency.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) why
resource allocation in
perfectly competitive
markets is socially efficient.

D9DFDC79106B4079A6C40B4559C7E04D.description:
Perfectly competitive
markets allocate
resources efficiently,
but imperfect
competition often
results in market
inefficiencies.

49D3B8512DC74C9389A117554C6925E6.description:
Quotas can be used to alter quantities produced and therefore
affect price, consumer surplus, and total economic surplus.

4C2B935E641F414894004C985308849B.description:
Tariffs, which governments sometimes use to influence
international trade, affect domestic price, quantity, government
revenue, and consumer surplus and total economic surplus.

6EDF70916FEB4F699081CD176C1A2AEA.description:
Equilibria in competitive markets may be altered by the decision
to open an economy to trade with other countries; equilibrium
price can be higher or lower than under autarky, and the gap
between domestic supply and demand is filled by trade. Opening
an economy to trade with other countries affects consumer
surplus, producer surplus, and total economic surplus.

0DCAF98CF6704189878585B1CCB6D429.description:
Define tariffs and quotas.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
markets are affected by
public policy related to
international trade.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from public policy related
to international trade.

87BD0022F5AA488283F522D884C11B68.description:
The incidence of taxes and subsidies imposed on goods traded
in perfectly competitive markets depends on the elasticity of
supply and demand.

C60FFC24C5F24BE286782E3D12CABB67.description:
Deadweight loss represents the losses to buyers and sellers as
a result of government intervention in an efficient market.

12DF7A99768A4CC5AEE3BC45CCDD3D87.description:
Government intervention in a market producing the efficient
quantity through taxes, subsidies, price controls, or quantity
controls can only decrease allocative efficiency

583AB004097644C786C09930CA63B623.description: Taxes and subsidies affect government revenues or costs.

DC39361AEB034782A2E9EC2B22004F12.description:
Governments use taxes and subsidies to change incentives in
ways that influence consumer and producer behavior, shifting
the supply and demand curves accordingly

BBD17049937B4607AC5EA9FF2B12EF2E.description:
Some government policies, such as price floors, price ceilings,
and other forms of price and quantity regulation, affect
incentives and outcomes in all market structures.

6B3FC75EACC94F8A99AD5BEBA838A68F.description:
Define forms of
government price and
quantity intervention.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
government policies alter
consumer and producer
behaviors that influence
incentives and therefore
affect outcomes.
c. Calculate (using data from
a graph or table where
appropriate) changes in
market outcomes resulting
from government policies

5F218374DF3D4030B11A69B43A4D95EC.description:
Government policies
influence consumer and
producer behavior and
therefore affect market
outcomes.

8AA43982CFE2432D9857524B917CFFDF.description:
When a typical firm hires additional workers in a monopsonistic
labor market, the marginal factor (resource) cost is greater than
the supply price of labor.

F0207C99B8A0492DA4CF9906D02AF79E.description:
In a monopsonistic labor market, a typical firm hires additional
labor as long as the marginal revenue product is greater than
the marginal factor (resource) cost (the wage of a new unit of
labor plus the wage increase given to all existing labor).

7FFA9481F613425E8AA58FAE892736A2.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of
monopsonistic markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) the
profit-maximizing behavior
of firms buying labor
(with other inputs fixed) in
monopsonistic markets.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
where appropriate)
measures representing the
profit-maximizing behavior
of firms buying labor
(with other inputs fixed) in
monopsonistic markets.

FF0910B32C7841C9AEF5396BE03CEA5B.description:
Marginal revenue product of a factor of production is the
change in total revenue divided by the change in that factor
of production, which is also equal to the marginal physical
product of that factor multiplied by the marginal revenue
(MRP = MP × MR). Firms in a perfectly competitive output market
will have marginal revenue product of labor that is equal to the
value of the marginal product of labor (VMPL = MPL × P ) because
marginal revenue for each unit of output is equal to price.

F4D05888E7714986987ECA5CAC2D19CB.description:
To minimize costs or maximize profits, firms allocate inputs
such that the last dollar spent on each input yields the same
amount of marginal product.

584E8198216146418E963AC4C216B63E.description:
In a perfectly competitive labor market, the wage is set
by the market and each firm hires the quantity of workers,
where the marginal factor (resource) cost (wage) equals the
marginal revenue product of labor. A typical firm may be a
perfect competitor in the labor market even if it is an imperfect
competitor in its output markets.

A8C0E6672667406EABFD9C7B6C8F5152.description:
In a perfectly competitive labor market, the wage is set
by the market and each firm hires the quantity of workers,
where the marginal factor (resource) cost (wage) equals the
marginal revenue product of labor. A typical firm may be a
perfect competitor in the labor market even if it is an imperfect
competitor in its output markets.

39341A8B48E04738A4E26EA1FCE236A8.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of
perfectly competitive
factor markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
the profit-maximizing
behavior of firms buying
labor (with other inputs
fixed) in perfectly
competitive markets.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
where appropriate)
measures representing
the profit-maximizing
behavior of firms buying
labor (with other inputs
fixed) in perfectly
competitive markets.

C3D249A5731E4E79B97D6B85BF18E27E.description:
Changes in the determinants of labor supply (such as
immigration, education, working conditions, age distribution,
availability of alternative options, preferences for leisure, and
cultural expectations) cause the labor supply curve to shift.

1A4C3CE622C244F0810434815E717097.description:
Changes in the determinants of labor demand, such as the
output price and the productivity of the worker, cause the labor
demand curve to shift.

CBC8FE46263E4A56959BFA73B31A6BCD.description:
Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) firms’
and factors’ responses
to changes in incentives
and constraints

61375C5B88FA4A4C9FC2C35C89D5B4AC.description:
The quantity of labor demanded is negatively related to
the wage rate, while the quantity of labor supplied is positively
related to the wage rate in a given labor market, other
things constant.

A93E2D791DA84354A1703758C64B4D7C.description:
Factors of production (labor, capital, and land) respond to
factor prices (wages, interest, and rent), and employers’ (firms’)
decision to hire is based on the productivity of the factors,
output price, and cost of the factor.

F79B23F6531745448F5ED1BC2F1A15FE.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to factor markets.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) the
relationship between
factors of production,
firms, and factor prices.
c. Calculate (using data from
a graph or table where
appropriate) the marginal
revenue product and
marginal resource cost

120DD008DB6A4942BF0A27156F01A893.description:
Factor prices provide
incentives and
convey information to
firms and factors of
production.

489B6F177C134DA59FB2BCF990824135.description:
Oligopolists have difficulty achieving the monopoly outcome
for reasons similar to those that prevent players from achieving
a cooperative outcome in the Prisoner’s Dilemma; nevertheless,
prices are generally higher and quantities lower with oligopoly
(or duopoly) than with perfect competition.

F9C0E70673C84AAFBB36112B53EC244B.description:
A Nash equilibrium is a condition describing the set of actions
in which no player can increase his or her payoff by unilaterally
taking another action, given the other players’ actions.

30826A157FD94C12931570135A6EDCF8.description:
A player has a dominant strategy when the payoff to a particular
action is always higher independent of the action taken by the
other player. Dominant strategies can be eliminated from each
player’s action set and can sometimes lead to an equilibrium
outcome (see Nash equilibrium below).

CB812DB46E4D45DFA1F4AAAD9B803896.description:
A game is a situation in which a number of individuals take
actions, and the payoff for each individual depends directly on
both the individual’s own choice and the choices of others.

3457E79EF283439DB3C20B60498267D5.description:
Firms in an oligopoly have an incentive to collude and form
cartels.

7DC2B58D2F574789B9FA276554B71FA8.description:
An oligopoly is an inefficient market structure with high barriers
to entry, where there are few firms acting interdependently.

D977171CD5D5490A910FFE525021340D.description:
a. Define (using tables as
appropriate) key terms,
strategies, and concepts
relating to oligopolies
and simple games.
b. Explain (using tables as
appropriate) strategies and
equilibria in simple games
and the connections to
theoretical behaviors in
various oligopoly market
and non-market settings.
c. Calculate (using tables as
appropriate) the incentive
sufficient to alter a player’s
dominant strategy.

25DC91ABBAA748848F91CE36F13B6AE8.description:
With perfect price discrimination, a monopolist produces the
quantity where price equals marginal cost (just as a competitive
market would) but extracts all economic surplus associated
with its product and eliminates all deadweight loss.

E2A03271050A465195F56C6295B1F227.description:
With perfect price discrimination, a monopolist produces the
quantity where price equals marginal cost (just as a competitive
market would) but extracts all economic surplus associated
with its product and eliminates all deadweight loss.

0524977D7385482CBF2BCAF53C3B4C5E.description:
A firm with market power can engage in price discrimination
to increase its profits or capture additional consumer surplus
under certain conditions.

C03E78A795104EAABDA3AECD50938405.description:
In a natural monopoly, long-run economies of scale for a single
firm exist throughout the entire effective demand of its product.

8BAE5648061B4C159DA42DAEDEA9AA5B.description:
In a monopoly, equilibrium (profit-maximizing) quantity is
determined by equating marginal revenue (MR) to marginal cost
(MC). The price charged is greater than the marginal cost.

10BA3DB4AD4A4BD4B78209BDB4583F2B.description: A monopoly exists because of barriers to entry.

09421FC7EF90406DBD2321093DD118F5.description:
Incentives to enter an industry may be mitigated by barriers to
entry. Barriers to entry—such as high fixed/start-up costs, legal
barriers to entry, and exclusive ownership of key resources—
can sustain imperfectly competitive market structures.

20C5A6EE45A848FDACDD987561D78D10.description:
In imperfectly competitive markets, consumers and producers
respond to prices that are above the marginal costs of
production and/or marginal benefits of consumption (i.e., price
is greater than marginal cost in an inefficient market).

8711CC4FD36B4A45A5C05072A1CC1815.description:
In imperfectly competitive output markets and assuming all else
is constant, a firm must lower price to sell additional units.

8C51D2DC895944759D79309A0873EE32.description:
Imperfectly competitive markets include monopoly, oligopoly,
and monopolistic competition in product markets and
monopsony in factor markets.

21C96D4F5C1A4059BFF54F9772316AE6.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate)
the characteristics of
imperfectly competitive
markets and inefficiency.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
equilibrium, firm decision
making, consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight loss
in imperfectly competitive
markets and why prices
in imperfectly competitive
markets cannot be relied
on to coordinate the
actions of all possible
market participants and
can lead to inefficient
outputs.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table
as appropriate) areas
of consumer surplus,
producer surplus, profit
(loss), and deadweight
loss in imperfectly
competitive markets.

DFEE3FA1FB4048E7A8F8561A4AB99A1D.description:
A perfectly competitive market in long-run equilibrium is
allocatively and productively efficient.

6745012B948E4DB6991DF54C25B1761F.description:
Firms may be in a constant cost, increasing cost, or decreasing
cost industry. Long-run prices depend on the portion of the
long-run cost curves on which firms operate.

31E1317DC2454832A4FF5761500AF813.description:
In a long-run perfectly competitive equilibrium, productive
efficiency implies all operating firms produce at efficient scale,
price equals marginal cost and minimum average total cost,
and firms earn zero economic profit.

F668E4C93980450DA00F3070E57667F1.description:
In a short-run competitive equilibrium, price can either be above
or below its long-run competitive level resulting in profits or
losses, motivating entry or exit of firms and moving prices and
quantities toward long-run equilibrium.

C4D05AB17FBB456085AAFF17845BB9F6.description:
At a competitive market equilibrium, the price of a product
equals both the private marginal benefit received by the last unit
consumed and the private marginal cost incurred to produce the
last unit, thus achieving allocative efficiency.

B89A37427BA54FEB8D0B30B6D6A6BEA7.description:
At a competitive market equilibrium, firms are price takers and
select output to maximize profit by producing the level of output
where the marginal cost equals marginal revenue (at the price).

D72C4B27E60641C79AA23C05BED7DE04.description:
In perfectly competitive markets, firms can sell all their outputs at
a constant price determined by the market.

14EFF904B5D049E88444D044E528993B.description:
In perfectly competitive markets, prices communicate to
consumers and producers the magnitude of others’ marginal
costs of production and marginal benefits of consumption and
provide incentives to act on that information (i.e., price equals
marginal cost in an efficient market).

F2EFD8049D2C4DC3B69B508D0BC0F9D0.description:
A perfectly competitive market is efficient. Firms in perfectly
competitive markets face no barriers to entry and have no
market power.

5FEB121079194B29ACD8A4BB7E2A3506.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
characteristics of perfectly
competitive markets and
efficiency.
b. Explain (using graphs where
appropriate) equilibrium
and firm decision making
in perfectly competitive
markets and how prices
in perfectly competitive
markets lead to efficient
outcomes.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) economic
profit (loss) in perfectly
competitive markets.

548BCC4359324B17ACE045E8BB239CB1.description:
Even with a
common goal of
profit-maximization,
market structure
constrains and
influences prices,
output, and efficiency.

363F607E09E745A292010DD667112535.description:
In the absence of barriers to entry or exit, in the long run (i.e., once
factors that are fixed in the short run become variable), firms
enter a market in which there are profit-making opportunities and
exit a market when they anticipate economic losses.

6304718318AE4654A7D365B0BF68F8E1.description:
In the short run, firms decide to operate (i.e., produce positive
output) or shut down (i.e., produce zero output) by comparing total
revenue to total variable cost or price to average variable cost (AVC).

B39F55C53B1F4625A20AB49E11F45FA9.description:
Explain (using graphs or data
where appropriate) firms’
short-run decisions to produce
positive output levels, or
long-run decisions to enter or
exit a market in response to
profit-making opportunities.

B70B24F8643B4248A8BD4F19F83B5B7F.description:
Firms’ short-run
decisions to produce
output, and long-run
decisions to enter
or exit a market, are
based on profitability.

D3524027A4634F1F98281536A598834F.description:
The minimum efficient scale plays a role in determining the
concentration of firms in a market and the market structure.

1372A1A596A240D1AA75A342596E7A37.description:
The long-run average total cost is characterized by economies
of scale, diseconomies of scale, or constant returns to scale
(efficient scale).

47CC679780FC4520B577B49D8F9FACBA.description:
The relationship between inputs and outputs in the long run is
described by the scale of production—increasing, decreasing,
or constant returns to scale.

C1845672B3174927B3F34CCE86A00A5F.description:
In the long run, firms can adjust all their inputs, and as a result,
all costs become variable.

A4450ECB4E4545A582AD490A1103AA5A.description:
Cost curves can shift in response to changes in input costs and
productivity.

BF9CD822C0474A00B8AA0635ACD59EA8.description:
Specialization and the division of labor reduce marginal costs
for firms.

47C282DAC052444DB6835DB6472FD2F8.description:
Production functions with diminishing marginal returns yield an
upward-sloping marginal cost curve.

7CC90E0028924492B55A0863E7D17282.description:
Marginal cost, average (fixed, variable, and total) cost, total cost,
and total variable cost change as total output changes, but total
fixed cost remains constant at all output levels, including zero
output.

F1770B47132048B1B5EE2141D87C8953.description: Fixed costs and variable costs determine the total cost.

70364C26D81944638138396B0C27EDBC.description:
Diminishing marginal returns occur as the firm employs more of
one input, holding other inputs constant, to produce a product
(output) in the short run.

ABABC57F4EC544B396F31B6BFE02A445.description:
Marginal product and average product change as input usage
changes, and hence, total product changes.

7BA40D936E37404D88EF897700F9342A.description:
The production function explains the relationship between
inputs and outputs both in the short run and the long run

38355CE9F1EF4C88A2184EBC5D6986DA.description:
a. Define (using graphs
where appropriate) key
terms and concepts
relating to production
and cost.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
production and cost are
related in the short run
and long run.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) the various
measures of productivity
and short-run and
long-run costs.

F5E8310E57794A0EA6CFF087CC4A61C5.description:
Firms’ production
and cost constraints
over different input
and output levels
shape optimal decisions
in the short run and
long run.

CD75C2807AB84420BC60373C34E2E162.description:
Firms are assumed to produce output to maximize their profits
by comparing marginal revenue and marginal cost.

28911BE042F34E26AB90D72B7F787584.description:
a. Define (using graphs or
data as appropriate) the
profit-maximizing rule.
b. Explain (using a graph or
data as appropriate) the
profit-maximizing level of
production.

FF05B543838743E08F22A450A0642C11.description:
Accounting profit fails to account for implicit costs (such as cost
of financial capital, compensation for risk, or an entrepreneur’s
time) which if fully compensated result in normal profit.

7B0DA7255C8243C093D532B060266B26.description:
Firms respond to economic profit (loss) rather than accounting
profit..

C01A063C95744BFB92138FEBD7EFD6FC.description:
a. Define the different types
of profit.
b. Explain how firms respond
to profit opportunities.
c. Calculate a firm’s profit
or loss.

770D62796AAB4E0AA726A0E70A664502.description:
The optimal quantity is achieved when marginal benefit is equal
to marginal cost or where total benefit is maximized.

3FAB9485ECB4472181F6448A4BEDD74B.description:
The optimal quantity at any point in time does not depend on
fixed costs (sunk costs) or fixed benefits that have already been
determined by past choices.

88E2A9A758784486AFA5CBD0D299621E.description:
Marginal analysis involves comparing the additional benefit of
increasing a given activity with the additional cost. Comparing
marginal benefit (MB) with marginal cost (MC) helps individuals
(firms) decide whether to increase, decrease, or maintain their
consumption (production) levels.

9AC85C95FCBF4D09B5C5EF9EFB65E9A7.description:
a. Define marginal analysis
and related terms.
b. Explain a decision
using marginal analysis
(using a table or a graph
when appropriate).

08127642F1314CB7BDE870BEC3659F97.description:
Consumers allocate their limited income to purchase the
combination of goods that maximizes their utility by
equating/comparing the marginal utility of the last dollar
spent on each good.

57F56528C5C64665B457FB3F77F9769A.description:
Consumers experience diminishing marginal utility in the
consumption of goods and services.

1B4F0F18A46847C2AED16AC6007150CE.description:
In a model of rational consumer choice, consumers are
assumed to make choices so as to maximize their total utility.

8E198A502AFB4ABFB10AEF194697D40B.description:
Consumers face constraints and have to make optimal
decisions accounting for these constraints.

1C94F1E5A45B4BE6869C7FEBD058C5EC.description:
a. Define the key assumptions
of consumer choice theory.
b. Explain (using a table
or graph as appropriate)
how a rational consumer’s
decision making involves
the use of marginal benefits
and marginal costs.
c. Calculate (using a
table or a graph when
appropriate) how a rational
consumer’s decision
making involves the use
of marginal benefits and
marginal costs.

1EBACD18882948779526392923553382.description:
To determine the
optimal level at which
to pursue an activity
whose total benefits
exceed total cost,
rational economic
agents compare
marginal benefits and
marginal costs.

5C49C9D7D0FE4CC8BF7827DBF9B2127C.description:
Some decisions permit rational agents to look at only marginal
benefit and marginal cost. Other decisions cannot be broken
down into increments in this way and must be evaluated by
looking at total benefits and total costs.

61851245B0774BE8B3CD5D04B66AFFB1.description:
Total net benefits, the difference between total benefits and
total costs, are maximized at the optimal choice

03CC76E3DB2F44B483B270D82EBD1EE7.description:
a. Explain a decision by
comparing total benefits
and total costs (using a
table or a graph when
appropriate).
b. Calculate total benefits and
total costs (using a table or
graph when appropriate).

E126C2D8BEF84E70BCF092E14D34FA14.description:
Total benefits form the metric “utility” for consumers and total
revenue for firms.

ECCB94AC9F0347A283D5C19B5A6878B0.description:
Rational agents consider opportunity costs, whether implicit
or explicit, when calculating the total economic costs of any
decision

0582FCA9A59C4DC88712695270D71390.description:
a. Define opportunity cost.
b. Explain the opportunity
costs associated with
choices.
c. Calculate the opportunity
costs associated with
choices.

B3BB776B293B4078BA72F08285D6FF3D.description:
Rational economic
decisions require
evaluation of costs
and benefits.

166230B1EEFE4C259B92C948976979EB.description:
Factors that shift the market demand and market supply curves
cause price, quantity, consumer surplus, producer surplus,
and total economic surplus (within that market) to change.
The impact of the change depends on the price elasticities of
demand and supply

962F28865DBD4C179B3580BB5D242E25.description:
Whenever markets experience imbalances—creating
disequilibrium prices and quantities, surpluses, and
shortages—market forces drive price and quantity toward
equilibrium.

DC83C43AA72547B0BEC8D74DA3135193.description:
a. Define a surplus and
shortage.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate) how
changes in underlying
conditions and shocks
to a competitive market
can alter price, quantity,
consumer surplus, and
producer surplus.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) changes in
price, quantity, consumer
surplus, and producer
surplus in response to
changes in market
conditions or market
disequilibrium.

007B551201C14AAB97E5AD9C9FE3F772.description:
Market equilibrium maximizes total economic surplus in the
absence of market failures, meaning that perfectly competitive
markets are efficient.

F12F84582A7146E48FA906969ED83624.description:
Economists use consumer surplus and producer surplus to
measure the benefits markets create to buyers and sellers and
understand market efficiency.

00A85BBF2BC04290AB9A2899258057B9.description: Equilibrium price provides information to economic decisionmakers to guide resource allocation.

DCCF9B185E664B69935CB72F539670D4.description:
In a perfectly competitive market, equilibrium is achieved
(and markets clear with no shortages or surpluses) when the
price of a good or service brings quantity supplied and quantity
demanded into balance, in the sense that buyers wish to
purchase the same quantity that sellers wish to provide.

42441D2936B9412CB04083509DBCC6B8.description:
The supply-demand model is a tool for understanding what
factors influence prices and quantities and why prices and
quantities might differ across markets or change over time.

60194065D425405F9B546D16A71AB211.description:
a. Define (using graphs
as appropriate) market
equilibrium, consumer
surplus, and producer
surplus.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how
equilibrium price, quantity,
consumer surplus, and
producer surplus for
a good or service are
determined.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or table as
appropriate) areas of
consumer surplus and
producer surplus at
equilibrium.

D9A5037AC31442C59DDE08889F28246F.description:
Although equilibria
are stable, an economy
can move from one
equilibrium to another
if market conditions
change.

505C583B6014479792891E8695985B8D.description:
Cross-price elasticity of demand is measured by the percentage
change in the quantity demanded of one good divided by the
percentage change in the price of another good. Economists
use the cross-price elasticity of demand to determine whether
goods are substitutes, complements, or not related.

64E9E20366644AF591AFE9E7C4FB0633.description:
Income elasticity of demand is measured by the percentage
change in the quantity demanded divided by the percentage
change in consumers’ income. Economists use the income
elasticity of demand to determine whether a good is normal
or inferior.

A33303ABA1524BF990D564D635BD7B41.description:
Elasticity can be measured for any determinant of demand or
supply, not just the price.

EC3CEAC3ACCA44448883D96846C0BC08.description:
The price elasticity of supply depends on certain factors such
as the price of alternative inputs.

8D0776B6BB3A448696D4BA8DB3959794.description:
Ranges of values of elasticity of supply are described as elastic
or inelastic with the separating benchmark being a magnitude
of 1, where the change in the price and the change in the
quantity supplied are proportional.
a. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is greater than
1, the supply is described as being elastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
b. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is less than 1,
the supply is described as being inelastic with respect to that
price in the range of the given change.
c. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is equal to 1,
the supply is described as being unit elastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.

5019EF1B33B34245B84625074B7F72FF.description:
Price elasticity of supply is measured by the percentage
change in quantity supplied divided by the percentage change
in price, or the responsiveness of the quantity supplied to
changes in price.

CDF7B9CB562D443C8366127FFD52C031.description:
The impact of a given price change on total revenue or total
expenditure will depend on whether demand is elastic, inelastic,
or unit elastic.

BB5E5B1AD8C945B1A259DA1D27ECA110.description:
The price elasticity of demand depends on certain factors such
as the availability of substitutes.

A1EE592D1BF9418991EA83C3AA4FE2CF.description:
Ranges of values of elasticity of demand are described as
elastic or inelastic with the separating benchmark being a
magnitude of 1, where the change in the price and the change
in the quantity demanded are proportional.
a. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is greater than 1,
the demand is described as being elastic with respect to that
price in the range of the given change.
b. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is less than 1,
the demand is described as being inelastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.
c. When the magnitude of the value of elasticity is equal to 1,
the demand is described as being unit elastic with respect to
that price in the range of the given change.

670C880AC3F54F0D8067786787F582F3.description:
Price elasticity of demand is measured by the percentage
change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage
change in price or the responsiveness of the quantity
demanded to changes in price. Elasticity varies along a linear
demand curve, meaning slope is not elasticity.

34F91124D7AC400BA3007A27CA4593CD.description:
Economists use the concept of elasticity to measure the
magnitude of percentage changes in quantity owing to any given
changes in the own-price, income, and prices of related goods

D381DC88AFF84984B2B06132244F301B.description:
a. Define measures of
elasticity.
b. Explain (using graphs
where appropriate)
measures of elasticity and
the impact of a given price
change on total revenue
or total expenditure.
c. Calculate (using data
from a graph or a table
as appropriate) measures
of elasticity.

5D98EBB14B8E4BB2AE3138942408D026.description:
Changes in the determinants of supply can cause the supply
curve to shift

C7D727C08F3547A2B0734A6928B6E6B9.description:
Explain (using graphs as
appropriate) producers’
(sellers’) responses to
changes in incentives and
technology.

02DDCFE5FE36409596EF5E0FD9D163E6.description:
The market supply curve (schedule) is derived from the
summation of individual supply curves (schedules). The market
supply curve is upward-sloping.

2E27DF33ADFB4FFDB633FE86305A95F9.description:
A change in own-price causes a change in quantity supplied in
the same direction and a movement along a supply curve.

F18D416F33F741949D02B5D82AF4538C.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) the law of
supply.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between price
and quantity supplied

5790F42A42594632896668DACAFD001B.description:
Changes in the determinants of consumer demand can cause
the demand curve to shift.

65884B3589874AE9B13B1DB17B8DF3F9.description:
Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) buyers’
responses to changes in
incentives and constraints.

6DEEA002E0AC47BF89647C734D71CDFD.description:
The market demand curve (schedule) is derived from the
summation of individual demand curves (schedules).

97AFE262286244F2943443B63B8B5617.description:
The conceptual relationship between price and quantity stated
by the law of demand leads to downward-sloping demand
curves explained by the income effect and substitution effect
and/or by diminishing marginal utility.

617AB56E046348E9A4B3884866E13D81.description:
The law of demand suggests that a change in the own-price
causes a change in quantity demanded in the opposite direction
and a movement along a demand (marginal benefit) curve.

D3DC6B382F1D4A689C0EAE5D8E7A2656.description:
Individuals often respond to incentives, such as those
presented by prices, but also face constraints, such as income,
time, and legal and regulatory frameworks.

D2D9DBC727F746959BF1466CB983129C.description:
A well-defined system of property rights is necessary for the
market system to function well.

A4745E3DD48E4E67AE8FDCBE72810BA0.description:
a. Define (using graphs as
appropriate) key terms
and factors related to
consumer decision making
and the law of demand.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) the
relationship between price
and quantity demanded
and how buyers respond to
incentives and constraints.

5FEDD5611FEA420D8AF8FFCB8D22320C.description:
Individuals and
firms respond to
incentives and face
constraints.

C80FF179AA3F412C8D9F65948883241B.description:
Comparative advantage and opportunity costs determine the
terms of trade for exchange under which mutually beneficial
trade can occur

B4C44A39BC624E2F8ED0E8D41D9AA100.description:
Production specialization according to comparative advantage,
not absolute advantage, results in exchange opportunities that
lead to consumption possibilities beyond the PPC.

B29DF48DC4C6467EBF8C1FB5B6E9C16B.description:
a. Explain (using data
from PPCs or tables
as appropriate) how
specialization according
to comparative advantage
with appropriate terms
of trade can lead to gains
from trade.
b. Calculate (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) mutually
beneficial terms of trade.

C4CE9E2A553D43EFAE01928B15EF04B7.description:
Comparative advantage describes a situation in which an
individual, business, or country can produce a good or service
at a lower opportunity cost than another producer.

6086C39D4D3B494CBC7724D1958AF5C6.description:
Absolute advantage describes a situation in which an individual,
business, or country can produce more of a good or service
than any other producer with the same quantity of resources.

7F5203CB06DD465F8A0A46B2234CFC35.description:
a. Define absolute advantage
and comparative
advantage.
b. Determine (using data
from PPCs or tables as
appropriate) absolute and
comparative advantage

4EA07F59D9014F5CB67CF4BEE3BA59FE.description:
The consequences of
scarcity can be
mitigated through
specialization in
production and by
exchange.

8F9776430C204CB1B4C9794D3946470A.description: Economic growth results in an outward shift of the PPC.

75F3692CAE4A463BBDC44426B57B08FE.description:
The PPC can shift due to changes in factors of production as
well as changes in productivity/technology

4E785177A2D048F0BF131CB3E23FC539.description:
The shape of the PPC depends on whether opportunity costs
are constant, increasing, or decreasing.

9D5F7ED149A04405A94AC5985B420B8E.description:
The PPC can be used to illustrate the concepts of scarcity,
opportunity cost, efficiency, underutilized resources, and
economic growth or contraction

D27C0DEFEE814ABC8115784E2A045365.description:
The PPC is a model used to show the trade-offs associated with
allocating resources.

904078E5F2044B288D42E11E232AC8D7.description:
Define (using graphs
as appropriate) the
production possibilities
curve (PPC) and
related terms.
b. Explain (using graphs
as appropriate) how the
production possibilities
curve (PPC) illustrates
opportunity costs,
trade-offs, inefficiency,
efficiency, and economic
growth or contraction
under various conditions.
c. Calculate (using
data from PPCs or
tables as appropriate)
opportunity cost

97AF6FDD76EB47A6A8E3CACC423562CE.description:
Resource allocation is significantly influenced by the economic
system adopted by society, such as command economy, market
economy, or mixed economy. Each system involves a particular
set of institutional arrangements and a coordinating mechanism
for allocating scarce resources and distributing output.

F39079AADE64498B82659CA5F5D4490F.description:
Resource allocation involves answering three basic questions—
What goods and services to produce? How to produce
those goods and services? And who consumes those goods
and services?

8997C0EFCA384D5DABFF58742EA93451.description:
Define how resource
allocation is influenced by the
economic system adopted
by society

11AA783185CC4900B19405C0DFB2EE04.description:
Most factors of production (such as land, labor, and capital) are
scarce, but some factors of production (such as established
knowledge) may not be scarce due to their non-rival nature

98F735C54DF6476FA9C235CDC9DBA69C.description:
Economic trade-offs arise from the lack of sufficient resources
(scarcity) to meet society’s wants and needs.

E204388D6BC24A139056A204157A7637.description:
Define resources and the
cause(s) of their scarcity.

D219C7A39BC04B098E66EEBB6C9389C3.description:
Most resources are
scarce, and in most
cases use of resources
involves constraints
and trade-offs.
